content.text: CSS Variables - The var() Function
CSS Variables
The var() function is used to insert the value of a CSS variable.
content.html: The var() function is used to insert the value of a CSS variable.

content.text: CSS variables have access to the DOM, which means that you can create variables with local or global scope, change the variables with JavaScript, and change the variables based on media queries.
content.html: CSS variables have access to the DOM, which means that you can create variables with local or global scope, change the variables with JavaScript, and change the variables based on media queries.

content.text: A good way to use CSS variables is when it comes to the colors of your design. Instead of copy and paste the same colors over and over again, you can place them in variables.
content.html: A good way to use CSS variables is when it comes to the colors of your design. Instead of copy and paste the same colors over and over again, you can place them in variables.

content.text: The Traditional Way
The following example shows the traditional way of defining some colors in a style sheet (by defining the colors to use, for each specific element):
content.html: The following example shows the traditional way of defining some colors in a style sheet (by defining the colors to use, for each specific element):

content.code_html:
body { background-color: #1e90ff; }

h2 { border-bottom: 2px solid #1e90ff; }

.container {
  color: #1e90ff;
  background-color: #ffffff;
  padding: 15px;
}

button {
  background-color: #ffffff;
  color: #1e90ff;
  border: 1px solid #1e90ff;
  padding: 5px;
}

content.text: Syntax of the var() Function
The var() function is used to insert the value of a CSS variable.
content.html: The var() function is used to insert the value of a CSS variable.

content.text: The syntax of the var() function is as follows:
content.html: The syntax of the var() function is as follows:

content.code_html:
Value Description
name Required. The variable name (must start with two dashes)
value Optional. The fallback value (used if the variable is not found)

content.text: Note: The variable name must begin with two dashes (--) and it is case sensitive!
content.html: Note: The variable name must begin with two dashes (--) and it is case sensitive!

content.text: How var() Works
First of all: CSS variables can have a global or local scope.
content.html: First of all: CSS variables can have a global or local scope.

content.text: Global variables can be accessed/used through the entire document, while local variables can be used only inside the selector where it is declared.
content.html: Global variables can be accessed/used through the entire document, while local variables can be used only inside the selector where it is declared.

content.text: To create a variable with global scope, declare it inside the :root selector. The :root selector matches the document's root element.
content.html: To create a variable with global scope, declare it inside the :root selector. The :root selector matches the document's root element.

content.text: To create a variable with local scope, declare it inside the selector that is going to use it.
content.html: To create a variable with local scope, declare it inside the selector that is going to use it.

content.text: The following example is equal to the example above, but here we use the var() function.
content.html: The following example is equal to the example above, but here we use the var() function.

content.text: First, we declare two global variables (--blue and --white). Then, we use the var() function to insert the value of the variables later in the style sheet:
content.html: First, we declare two global variables (--blue and --white). Then, we use the var() function to insert the value of the variables later in the style sheet:

content.code_html:
:root {
  --blue: #1e90ff;
  --white: #ffffff;
}

body { background-color: var(--blue); }

h2 { border-bottom: 2px solid var(--blue); }

.container {
  color: var(--blue);
  background-color: var(--white);
  padding: 15px;
}

button {
  background-color: var(--white);
  color: var(--blue);
  border: 1px solid var(--blue);
  padding: 5px;
}

content.text: Advantages of using var() are:
To change the blue and white color to a softer blue and white, you just need to change the two variable values:
content.html: To change the blue and white color to a softer blue and white, you just need to change the two variable values:

content.code_html:
:root {
  --blue: #6495ed;
  --white: #faf0e6;
}

body { background-color: var(--blue); }

h2 { border-bottom: 2px solid var(--blue); }

.container {
  color: var(--blue);
  background-color: var(--white);
  padding: 15px;
}

button {
  background-color: var(--white);
  color: var(--blue);
  border: 1px solid var(--blue);
  padding: 5px;
}

Function Description
var() Inserts the value of a CSS variable
